results.title: Kismet
results.creator_credit: Vincente Minnelli, Arthur Freed and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Kismet is an enchanting musical filled with sensual dance and magical song. Howard Keel plays the witty poet-beggar whose quick tongue is forever getting him in trouble…and out again. Masquerading as Hajj, a famous sorcerer with magic powers, he has just the right amount of charm to turn a fair lady’s head, a fair lady who happens to be the Wazir’s Number One Wife! Cast also includes Ann Blyth, Dolores Grey, Vic Damone.

results.title: Kiru umi no yoni / Cutting like the ocean
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
One of Callas’ most personally confronting works, it is made up of six parts, and utilises the image of a knife slicing horizontally through the pictorial screen as its central and linking motif. Its starting point was an installation by Callas which incorporated a photograph from the 1920s of two severed heads belonging to a male and female of an indigenous tribe in Formosa (Taiwan). At once horrific and enigmatic, this image forms a potent metaphor for Japan’s pre-Second World War imperial past. The significance of the work is not confined to Japan alone - it also offers a kind of mirror with which to face atrocities committed in colonial Australia.

Produced with the assistance of the Australian Film Commission.
Notes by Rachel Kent, reprinted courtesy of the author and d/Lux Media Arts.

results.title: Kirikou and the sorceress [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Michel Ocelot, Jacques Vercruyssen, Paul Thiltges, Didier Brunner, France 3 Cinema, Monipoly Productions, Odec Kid Cartoons and Les Armateurs
results.brief_description: A delightful animated fable, “Kirikou and the sorceress” starts with a child, Kirikou, speaking to his mother from the womb. Once born, Kirikou seeks about healing his village - principally from the curse that an ill-tempered sorceress has placed on the village including drying up the wells and eating up the men-folk. In his bid to confront the sorceress and see the end to his tribe’s woes, Kirikou undertakes a perilous journey meeting an array of colourful beings and jungle creatures. The charm of the narrative is that it presents from a child’s perspective with uncomplicated views on life, unsullied by conjecture and misguided beliefs. The African village where this whimsical tale is set is abundant with colour, humour, culture and magic, with animation inspired by the earth colours and myths of Africa and imbued with a rich palette reminiscent of 19th century French painter Henri Rousseau. Music scored by Senegalese musician Youssou N’dour.

results.title: Kiribati? Here we are
results.creator_credit: John Shaw, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description: On 12 July 1979 the Gilbert Islands, in the Central Pacific Ocean, became independent from British rule. The film shows the way of life of the people and includes a brief historical background.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Shaw, Don Murray and Film Australia

results.title: Kiribati
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Oceans of Dreams - Currents of Change Series”.
Kiribati becomes an independent nation in 1979. The Republic comprises 33 coral atolls, formerly the Gilbert, Phoenix and Line Island groups. The atolls are often no more than a few metres above sea level, extremely narrow and with scant soil and surface water. Kiribati’s 719 square kilometres must support a population of approximately 65,000. What the land lacks in natural resources is compensated for by a vast ocean economic zone (3 million square kilometres), straddling the equator and stretching from near Hawaii in the North to Tuvala and Fiji in the south. The film looks at contemporary and traditional life, the challenges and changes which this Republic faces today.

results.title: Kiri Te Kanawa at Christmas
results.brief_description: A magical live performance from the Barbican Hall in London with Dame Kiri Te Kanawa singing her favourite Christmas songs. They include “Let the Bright Seraphim”, “Angels from the Realms of Glory” and “Silver Bells”. Dame Kiri is accompanied by the Philharmonic Orchestra, conducted by Carl Davis, and the Tallis Chamber Choir.

results.title: Kiri Te Kanawa
results.brief_description: Accompanied by well-known pianist Richard Amner, Dame Kiri offers a selection of pieces from various composers, including Schubert’s “Gretchen Am Spinnrade”, Strauss’ “Muttertandelei” and three delightful pieces from Walton with poems by Dame Edith Sitwell “Through Golden Trellises”, “Daphne” and “Old Sir Faulk”.

results.title: Kipling's India
results.creator_credit: Lloyd Capps, Alan Bateman and Australian Broadcasting Commission
results.brief_description: 19th century author, Rudyard Kipling spent the first six years of his life in Bombay where his father taught sculpture. After schooling in Britain, he returned to India to work for seven years as a journalist before returning forever to England to write full time. Although he never returned to India, Kipling never lost his delight in the romance, mystery and endless variety of Indian life. India formed his imagination and provided his best themes. In this program, Keith Adam retraces the journey of Kipling’s character Kim, to locate traces of the old India Kipling loved, and in doing so exposes us to the fascination of India.
